docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Let Mullah Omar Get Away,''by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, Dec. 26):    More than 3,000 people were killed on Sept. 11. Mullah Muhammad Omar allowed Osama bin Laden to use his country to plan these killings.    HERB KASSOFF ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Let Mullah Omar Get Away,''by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, Dec. 26): More than 3,000 people were killed on Sept. 11. Mullah Muhammad Omar allowed Osama bin Laden to use his country to plan these killings. HERB KASSOFF Fresh Meadows, Queens Dec. 26, 2001
docs.abstract: Herb Kassoff letter on Nicholas D Kristof's Dec 26 column notes Mullah Muhammad Omar let Osama bin Laden use Afghanistan to plan Sept 11 attacks; drawing

docs.snippet: An Afghan defense official said tonight that Osama bin Laden had escaped the country and was hiding in the mountainous border region of Pakistan. The Pentagon dismissed the report but said it had no idea of his whereabouts.    The report came as t...
docs.lead_paragraph: An Afghan defense official said tonight that Osama bin Laden had escaped the country and was hiding in the mountainous border region of Pakistan. The Pentagon dismissed the report but said it had no idea of his whereabouts. The report came as the Pentagon said American warplanes destroyed a compound in eastern Afghanistan that it believes was used by the chief of intelligence for the Taliban. Local villagers said as many as 40 civilians were killed, but the Pentagon said that while some civilians may have been in the compound, it could not confirm the casualty figure. It insisted that the target was a Taliban leadership headquarters.
docs.abstract: Afghan Defense Ministry aide Muhammad Habeel says Osama bin Laden escaped nation and is hiding in mountainous border region of Pakistan; says bin Laden is under protection of Mullah Fazlur Rehman and is trying to regroup his forces after being essentially routed from Afghanistan; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld dismisses report; says he does not know where bin Laden is or if he is alive; Pentagon reports American warplanes destroyed eastern Afghanistan complex believed used by Taliban intelligence chief, apparently killing him (M)

headline.main: Bin Laden Fled Into Pakistan, Afghans Report

byline.original: By AMY WALDMAN with ERIC SCHMITT

docs.snippet: The White House tried mightily today to dismiss the arguments about how the United States treats captives of the war in Afghanistan as an abstruse argument among government lawyers, rather than a fundamental split between America and its allies, o...
docs.lead_paragraph: The White House tried mightily today to dismiss the arguments about how the United States treats captives of the war in Afghanistan as an abstruse argument among government lawyers, rather than a fundamental split between America and its allies, or between Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and other leaders of President Bush's national security team. But clearly, the dispute is over something deeper than just legalisms.
docs.abstract: Analysis: dispute within Bush administration about how captives of war in Afghanistan should be classified and treated is over something deeper than just legalisms; there is ideological aversion among leading members of administration--led by Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld--to be bound by aging international treaties in era of new conflicts; that view causes problems for Secretary of State Colin Powell, whose job it is to keep fragile international coalition together for war on terrorism; some aides say Pres Bush's decision that captives are not prisoners of war was made in informal discussions, and without fully consulting Powell, who was traveling at the time (M)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your ''Portraits of Grief'' series (news article, Dec. 31) has reminded us of the real people whose lives  might otherwise have remained hidden behind a death toll. If only we could read similarly humanizing stories about the men...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your ''Portraits of Grief'' series (news article, Dec. 31) has reminded us of the real people whose lives might otherwise have remained hidden behind a death toll. If only we could read similarly humanizing stories about the men, women and children killed in other countries -- say, in Afghanistan by United States bombs in recent weeks.
docs.abstract: Alfie Kohn letter on Dec 31 article on Portrait of Grief sketches of World Trade Center terrorism victims calls for similar effort to humanize people in Afghanistan killed by United States bombs

headline.main: One by One: A Roll Call of Loss

docs.snippet: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo told a visiting United States congressman that the military was doing all it could to free two Americans and a Filipino woman being held hostage by Abu Sayyaf, a Muslim rebel group in the southern Philippines. The...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo told a visiting United States congressman that the military was doing all it could to free two Americans and a Filipino woman being held hostage by Abu Sayyaf, a Muslim rebel group in the southern Philippines. The military has failed to meet several recent self-imposed deadlines for a rescue. A government spokesman said Representative Todd Tiahrt, Republican of Kansas, had said that he wanted American troops to aid in a rescue but that the proposal was turned down. Seth Mydans (NYT)
docs.abstract: Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo tells Rep Todd Tiahrt, visiting American congressman, that Philippine military is doing all it can to free two Americans and Filipino woman being held hostage by Abu Sayyaf, Muslim rebel group; Philippines says it rejected his suggestion that American troops aid in rescue (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Assurance On U.S. Hostages

docs.snippet: President Bush's envoy to Afghanistan suggested today that American military forces might intervene in local conflicts in the absence of international troops stationed around the country.    The envoy, Zalmay Khalilzad, reiterated White House oppo...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's envoy to Afghanistan suggested today that American military forces might intervene in local conflicts in the absence of international troops stationed around the country. The envoy, Zalmay Khalilzad, reiterated White House opposition to expanding the international security force from Kabul to other Afghan cities. But he left open the possibility that without such forces in place, the responsibility for settling disputes between local warlords could land on the American military.
docs.abstract: Zalmay Khalilzad, Pres Bush's envoy, suggests American military forces might intervene in local conflicts between warlords in Afghanistan, news conference; reiterates Bush's opposition to expanding international security force from Kabul to other cities (M)

headline.main: U.S. Forces May Keep Order In Afghanistan Countryside

docs.snippet: AT a time when patriotic fervor and flag-waving is at a peak throughout the country, a group of Westchester teenagers has been meeting for four months to rehearse for a play that challenges the status quo. It's a work that scorns authority, is def...
docs.lead_paragraph: AT a time when patriotic fervor and flag-waving is at a peak throughout the country, a group of Westchester teenagers has been meeting for four months to rehearse for a play that challenges the status quo. It's a work that scorns authority, is defiantly antiwar and knocks social conventions rights off their pedestals. The play is ''Hair,'' which opened in 1968; the production is being staged by Cagle & Company with a cast of 29, ranging in age from 14 to 16 at the Irvington Town Hall Theater this weekend. The theater has been transformed into an icon of the counterculture 1960's, with beaded door dividers, antiwar posters and flower children escorting members of the audience to their seats.
docs.abstract: Cagle & Company, with cast of 29 ranging in age from 14 to 16, is staging production of Hair at Irvington Town Hall Theater in Irvington, NY; cast members comment on anti-war protests during Vietnam era and reflect on America's role in war in Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline.main: Still 'Hair,' but in a Patriotic Season

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Nicholas D. Kristof's suggestion that the United States should let Mullah Muhammad Omar get away (column, Dec. 26) stems from the mistaken assumption that the primary goal of the United States is to restore order to war-torn Afgh...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's suggestion that the United States should let Mullah Muhammad Omar get away (column, Dec. 26) stems from the mistaken assumption that the primary goal of the United States is to restore order to war-torn Afghanistan. The American campaign clearly has other foreign policy goals. One is to make an example of Mullah Omar, to show what happens to the leader of a country that supports terrorism. Whether or not one agrees with that policy, sending a message to Saddam Hussein is now America's highest priority. JACK DRESCHER New York, Dec. 26, 2001
docs.abstract: Jack Drescher letter on Nicholas D Kristof's Dec 26 column holds United States should make example of Mullah Muhammad Omar to show what happens to leader of country that supports terrorism; drawing

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The tragic story of the life, and death, of Marjan, the lion at Kabul's zoo (Reporter's Notebook, Feb. 4), brought to mind this quotation from Mohandas K. Gandhi, a man who well understood the interconnectedness of animal and hum...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The tragic story of the life, and death, of Marjan, the lion at Kabul's zoo (Reporter's Notebook, Feb. 4), brought to mind this quotation from Mohandas K. Gandhi, a man who well understood the interconnectedness of animal and human liberation: ''The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are treated.'' CYNTHIA A. BRANIGAN Hope, Pa., Feb. 5, 2002 The writer is president of Make Peace With Animals.
docs.abstract: Cynthia A Branigan letter on Feb 4 Reporter's Notebook article on behind-the-scenes events in war on terrorism in Afghanistan

docs.snippet: John Walker, the American wanderer turned Taliban warrior, was charged today in a criminal complaint with conspiring to kill United States citizens and supporting terrorist groups. He will be tried in federal court in Alexandria, Va., and could fa...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Walker, the American wanderer turned Taliban warrior, was charged today in a criminal complaint with conspiring to kill United States citizens and supporting terrorist groups. He will be tried in federal court in Alexandria, Va., and could face life in prison if convicted. The complaint against the 20-year-old California man said he trained in explosives and firearms at a Qaeda camp and fought shoulder to shoulder with the Taliban before he was captured in November near Mazar-i-Sharif. The charges ended a sharp debate within the Bush administration over whether Mr. Walker would be charged in a civilian court or in a military court-martial.
docs.abstract: John Walker, American who fought with Taliban in Afghanistan, is charged with conspiring to kill Americans and supporting terrorist groups; will be tried in federal court; complaint, which holds he trained at Al Qaeda camp and fought with Taliban, ends sharp debate within Bush administration over whether to try him in military court; Atty Gen John Ashcroft says Walker told FBI that he met Osama bin Laden in small group and knew bin Laden ordered Sept 11 terrorist attacks; FBI holds Walker admitted he learned in June that bin Laden ordered suicide mission in United States and learned of attacks while serving on Taliban front line; his family issues statement supporting him; photos (M)

headline.main: WALKER WILL FACE TERRORISM COUNTS IN A CIVILIAN COURT
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AMERICAN PRISONER
